Course Description: This course introduces students to: (i) the fundamental principles, theory, algorithms, and data structures behind digital representation, compression, synchronization, and processing of image, audio, and video data types, and (ii) challenges and issues in developing media-rich applications, such as media streaming and media retrieval. Students will be exposed to the workings of common media file formats and common manipulation techniques on media data.

Course Outcomes.CO1: Be confident in developing software and systems that capture, generate, store, and manipulate digital media.
Course Outcomes.CO2: Be able to make appropriate design decisions to trade-off between different computation resources (CPU time, storage, bandwidth) and media quality in choosing a media representation and
Course Outcomes.CO3: Be equipped with fundamental knowledge to pursue multimedia-related topics in depth.
Course Outcomes.CO4: Use evaluation strategies to analyze results, preparing report, and visually present the insights

R. Steinmetz and K. Nahrstedt, "Multimedia Applications", Springer, 2013.
R. R. Shah and R. Zimmermann, "Multimodal Analysis of User-Generated Multimedia Content", Springer, 2017.
Dan Jurafsky and James H. Martin, "Speach and Language Processing".
